channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘A True Disappointment’: When Your First Pride March Is Canceled
item.description: The coronavirus has led to the canceling of the big gatherings that have defined Pride. For many, that means missing out, for now, on an important moment of visibility and acceptance.
item.dc:creator: Pierre-Antoine Louis
item.media:description: The Pride March in New York last year celebrated the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall protests.

item.title: ‘We Could Be Feeling This for the Next Decade’: Virus Hits College Towns
item.description: Opening bars and bringing back football teams have led to new outbreaks. Communities that evolved around campuses face potentially existential losses in population, jobs and revenue.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Tommy Ly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The nearly deserted campus of the University of California, Davis, this month.

item.title: Florida’s Covid Cases Up Fivefold in 2 Weeks: ‘The Numbers Are Scary’
item.description: A surge in coronavirus cases has prompted officials to prohibit alcohol sales in bars and close Miami beaches for the coming holiday. But will it be enough?
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miami on Saturday. On Saturday for the second straight day, Florida has crushed its record for new coronavirus cases.

item.title: Mississippi Lawmakers Vote to Retire State Flag Rooted in the Confederacy
item.description: The flag, which has flown since 1894, is poised to come down, becoming yet another emblem of the Confederacy to be removed across the South.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:description: A Mississippi state flag at the Capitol in Jackson on Thursday.

item.title: Madeline McWhinney Dale, Trailblazing Banker, Is Dead at 98
item.description: She was the first female officer of the Federal Reserve Bank. Later, in another first, she ran a commercial bank largely owned and operated by women.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:description: Madeline McWhinney Dale in an undated photo. In 1960, she became the first female officer of the Federal Reserve Bank.

item.title: Remdesivir, the First Coronavirus Drug, Gets a Price Tag
item.description: Federal health officials and Gilead Sciences have settled on priority distribution to Americans — and nonnegotiable pricing.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: Rubber stoppers are fitted onto vials of remdesivir at a plant in the United States. Gilead Sciences and the federal government on Monday announced a plan for pricing and distributing the drug.

item.title: Texas Prosecutor Resigns Over Facebook Post About Nazi Germany
item.description: The post, shared last week by Kaylynn Williford, was criticized for appearing to equate protesters against racism and police brutality with Nazis who “tore down statues.”
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Steve Gonzales/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kaylynn Williford in court last year. She resigned as a prosecutor with the District Attorney’s Office in Harris County, Texas, over a Facebook post that the office said was “inappropriate.”

item.title: Ruth Buchanan, Philanthropist and Hostess Extraordinaire, Is Dead at 101
item.description: She and her husband, an ambassador who later served as White House chief of protocol, presided over grand gatherings in Washington and Newport, R.I.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: The heiress and philanthropist Ruth Buchanan in 1966. She said the woman in the mirror looked “a little like Medusa.”

item.title: Democrats Detail a Climate Agenda Tying Environment to Racial Justice
item.description: The policy road map, expected on Tuesday, could guide the party if it gains control of Congress and the White House in November.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: Rep. Kathy Castor, Democrat of Florida, during a House committee meeting last month.

item.title: 5 BRs, Pool/Hot Tub, Mediterranean Vu; Too Far to Commute to Jerusalem
item.description: The United States has put the ambassador to Israel’s Malibu-style seaside estate on the market. It can be yours for only $87 million.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger

item.title: Abortion Rises as a Pivotal Issue for At-Risk Senate Republicans
item.description: The Supreme Court’s rejection of a restrictive Louisiana abortion law, and Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh’s dissent, may create new challenges for Susan Collins and other Republican senators up for re-election.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, outside the Senate Chamber this month. The Supreme Court ruling on abortion has underscored what may be one of her biggest vulnerabilities.

item.title: Twitch Suspends Trump’s Channel for ‘Hateful Conduct’
item.description: The action appeared to be the first outright suspension of one of the president’s social media accounts.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Twitch, the livestreaming platform, said on Monday that it was suspending President Trump’s channel.

item.title: Trump Shares Video of Armed White Couple Confronting Protesters
item.description: A day after sharing on Twitter a video with a supporter yelling “white power,” the president retweeted a tense episode in St. Louis.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the past, President Trump has positioned himself as a strong defender of Second Amendment rights.

item.title: What to Do This Week
item.description: Start your summer reading, learn about leaping lemurs, and actually enjoy the fireworks this week.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Moss and Adriana Balsamo

item.title: How The Times Is Counting Every Coronavirus Case in the Country
item.description: The effort began with one reporter’s spreadsheet, and expanded with contributions from dozens of people with varying skill sets across the newsroom.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bures
item.media:description: A map showed where the number of coronavirus cases was slowing, steady or growing on June 25.

item.title: Reddit, Acting Against Hate Speech, Bans ‘The_Donald’ Subreddit
item.description: The influential pro-Trump community broke the rules on harassment and targeting, said Reddit, which also banned other groups.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The_Donald” subreddit, now banned by Reddit, is home to more than 790,000 users who post memes, viral videos and supportive messages about President Trump.

item.title: Lawmakers Press for Answers on Russian Bounty Offers to Taliban to Kill U.S. Troops
item.description: Democrats asked for Trump administration intelligence officials to brief lawmakers on what they knew about a suspected Russian plot.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi requested that all members of the House be briefed on intelligence about a suspected Russian plot against U.S. troops.

item.title: The Supreme Court Stopped Anti-Abortion Momentum. For Now.
item.description: The movement has a long pipeline of new cases that, if taken up by the Supreme Court, could present a more direct challenge to Roe v. Wade.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise and Elizabeth Dias
item.media:description: An anti-abortion protester reacted outside the Supreme Court after it struck down a contentious Louisiana state abortion law in Washington on Monday.

item.title: As Coronavirus Cases Surge, Families Struggle to Draw Boundaries
item.description: States are rushing to reopen and parents are left to decide for themselves what is safe.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Charlotte Kesl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sophia Gholz, 39, of Jacksonville, Fla., with her son, Hunter Olson, 5. Gholz said her family has tried to avoid socializing outside with others during the pandemic.

item.title: Golden State Killer Cases: Joseph DeAngelo Pleads Guilty
item.description: The string of rapes and murders stretched back to the 1970s. On Monday, in a converted ballroom in Sacramento, the former police officer admitted his guilt.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy and Tim Arango
item.media:description: Joseph James DeAngelo, a former police officer, pleaded guilty on Monday to 13 murders attributed to the Golden State Killer.

item.title: Another Fatal Shooting in Seattle’s ‘CHOP’ Protest Zone
item.description: City officials have vowed to dismantle the free-protest area set up during anti-police demonstrations and retake the Capitol Hill police station. But worries of confrontation have delayed a resolution.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Johnson
item.media:description: The scene of a fatal shooting in the Capitol Hill Occupied Protest zone of Seattle on Monday.

item.title: Even the South Pole Is Warming, and Quickly, Scientists Say
item.description: Surface air temperatures at the bottom of the world have risen three times faster than the global average since the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The American buildings of the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station.

item.title: In Court, Derek Chauvin’s Lawyers Say Officials Have Biased the Case
item.description: The Minneapolis police chief recently described George Floyd’s death as murder. Lawyers for the four officers charged in the case say that may have biased potential jurors.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango
item.media:credit: Hennepin County Jail, via Getty Images
item.media:description: From left, the former officers Derek Chauvin, Tou Thao, J. Alexander Kueng and Thomas Lane, who are charged in the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

item.title: Supreme Court Lifts Limits on Trump’s Power to Fire Consumer Watchdog
item.description: The case concerning the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was part of a politically charged battle over presidential authority.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Alan Rappeport
item.category: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
item.media:description: In the case the Supreme Court agreed to hear, both sides agreed that the bureau’s structure violated the Constitution.

item.title: Two Friends in Texas Were Tested for Coronavirus. One Bill Was $199. The Other? $6,408.
item.description: It’s an example of the unpredictable way health prices can vary for patients who receive identical care.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff
item.media:credit: Mary Inhea Kang for The New York Times
item.media:description: As a precaution before a camping trip, Jimmy Harvey and Pam LeBlanc were tested for coronavirus at the same place in Austin. Their financial experiences, though, were very different.

item.title: Louisiana Abortion Law Struck Down by Supreme Court
item.description: The case, over a state law requiring doctors performing abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals, is the first abortion ruling since two Trump appointees joined the court.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Anti-abortion demonstrators in front of the Supreme Court on Monday in Washington.

item.title: Federal Executions Can Restart After Supreme Court Declines a Case
item.description: The move clears the way for the executions of four men in the coming months after a 17-year gap during which no inmate on death row for federal crimes was put to death.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Two Supreme Court Justices said they would have heard the case.

item.title: How the Pandemic Is Making It Tougher to Study Whales
item.description: Monday: Whales are dying at alarming rates, but the pandemic is keeping researchers away. Also: Gov. Gavin Newsom closes bars in some counties.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Vatcheva
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palm trees were reflected in the window of a restaurant in Santa Monica that has remained closed, with its tables and chairs stacked.

item.title: Pelosi on Trump and Russia: ‘This Is as Bad as it Gets’
item.description: Russian meddling (in Afghanistan) and a racist retweet. This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: American Exceptionalism on the Virus
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Lines of cars wait at a coronavirus testing site in Miami Gardens, Fla.

item.title: Stock Market Live News and Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Trump’s Self-Inflicted Wound: Losing Swing Voters As He Plays to His Base
item.description: The president’s support among bedrock Republicans is almost certainly not enough to win him a second term in the White House, as even some G.O.P. leaders concede.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:description: Supporters cheered as President Trump spoke at a rally this month in Tulsa, Okla.

item.title: Trump Is Running on the Courts Again. Should Biden Do the Same?
item.description: President Trump’s promises to evangelicals on judges were a key part of shoring up support in 2016. Some Biden backers want to see him run on the courts this time, too.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:description: President Trump won over wary conservative voters in 2016 by releasing a list of prospective Supreme Court justices. Progressives have suggested former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should do the same this year.

item.title: Bagged Salads Recalled After Hundreds Are Sickened in the Midwest
item.description: The C.D.C. urged consumers in eight states to avoid four different salad kits produced by Fresh Express.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: More than 200 people reported getting sick after eating bagged salads, which were produced at a plant outside Chicago.

item.title: ‘Feeling Like Death’: Inside a Houston Hospital Bracing for a Virus Peak
item.description: As young patients fill new virus wards, Houston Methodist is calling nurses to work extra shifts and ramping up its testing efforts.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.media:description: Melissa Estrada, 37, receiving oxygen in a hospital room at Houston Methodist Hospital in Houston on Saturday.

item.title: Mask Exemption Cards From the ‘Freedom to Breathe Agency’? They’re Fake
item.description: The group, which is selling the cards online, is not a real government organization, federal officials said.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
